<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>VISA INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>September 30, 2008 </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(in millions, except as noted) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">not opted out of that settlement. In December 2007, GMRI, Inc. and Visa U.S.A. agreed in principle to resolve the claims brought against Visa U.S.A. and Visa
International through binding mediation. GMRI, Inc. and Visa U.S.A. participated in the binding mediation session in March 2008 and are now negotiating the non-financial terms of a settlement agreement. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>&#147;Indirect Purchaser&#148; Actions </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">In addition,
complaints have been filed in 19 different states and the District of Columbia alleging state antitrust, consumer protection and common law claims against Visa U.S.A. and MasterCard (and, in California Visa International) on behalf of putative
classes of consumers. The claims in these actions largely mirror the allegations made in the U.S. merchant lawsuit and assert that merchants, faced with excessive merchant discount fees, have passed on some portion those fees to consumers in the
form of higher prices on goods and services sold. Visa U.S.A. has been successful in the majority of these cases, as courts in 17 jurisdictions have granted Visa U.S.A.&#146;s motions to dismiss for failure to state a claim or plaintiffs have
voluntarily dismissed their complaints. The parties are awaiting a decision on Visa U.S.A.&#146;s motion to dismiss in New Mexico. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">In California,
the court granted Visa U.S.A. and Visa International&#146;s demurrer, or motion to dismiss, with respect to claims brought under the Cartwright Act, but denied a similar motion with respect to Unfair Competition Law claims for unlawful, unfair
and/or fraudulent business practices. Visa U.S.A. and Visa International subsequently filed a motion for judgment on the pleadings seeking dismissal of those latter claims in light of the Proposition 64 amendments to the Unfair Competition Law.
After oral argument, the court denied this motion on March&nbsp;6, 2007. The California Court of Appeal rejected a petition seeking immediate review of that decision on June&nbsp;7, 2007. On July&nbsp;24, 2007, a case management conference was held
at which the court permitted certain further discovery and agreed to address plaintiffs&#146; proposed motion for collateral estoppel with respect to certain elements of a &#147;tying&#148; claim based on statements in the decision on cross-motions
for summary judgment in <I>In re Visa Check/MasterMoney Antitrust Litigation</I>. On October&nbsp;31, 2007, the court denied the plaintiffs&#146; collateral estoppel motion. On October&nbsp;3, 2008, the parties agreed to confidential settlement
terms to resolve the dispute and are negotiating a settlement agreement that will be subject to court approval. The amount of the settlement is not material to the Company&#146;s financial statements taken as a whole. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">In West Virginia, the action was brought against Visa U.S.A. by West Virginia&#146;s attorney general as <I>parens patriae</I> for West Virginia consumers. The
court denied Visa U.S.A.&#146;s motion for summary judgment on October&nbsp;14, 2005. On February&nbsp;14, 2006, Visa U.S.A. answered the West Virginia complaint and the parties began discovery. On April&nbsp;10, 2007, the court issued a stay of
discovery pending its ruling on an antitrust standing issue. On April&nbsp;27, 2007, Visa U.S.A. and the State of West Virginia reached an agreement in principle to settle all claims against Visa U.S.A. A loss provision was recorded in Visa
U.S.A.&#146;s consolidated statements of operations in connection with this settlement. At a hearing on June&nbsp;2, 2008, the court approved a notice and exclusion plan for the settlement with the state of West Virginia. At a hearing on
August&nbsp;20, 2008, the court granted final approval of the settlement and reserved for later resolution only an application by West Virginia&#146;s counsel for attorneys&#146; fees and costs not to exceed the amount agreed upon in the settlement.
The court&#146;s order and final judgment approving the settlement and dismissing all claims against Visa U.S.A. with prejudice was entered on August&nbsp;22, 2008. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">184 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>VISA INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>September 30, 2008 </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(in millions, except as noted) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B><I>Department of Justice Antitrust Case and Related Litigation </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">In
October 1998, the U.S. Department of Justice, or DOJ, filed suit against Visa U.S.A., Visa International and MasterCard in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York alleging that both Visa U.S.A.&#146;s and MasterCard&#146;s
governance structures and policies violated U.S. federal antitrust laws. On October&nbsp;9, 2001, the District Court issued an opinion upholding the legality and pro-competitive nature of &#147;dual governance,&#148; the situation where an employee
of a member financial institution also serves on the board of directors of Visa U.S.A. or MasterCard while a portion of its card portfolio is issued under the brand of the other association. However, the court also held that Visa U.S.A.&#146;s bylaw
2.10(e), which prohibited Visa members from issuing American Express or Discover cards, and a similar MasterCard rule constituted unlawful restraints of trade under the federal antitrust laws. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On November&nbsp;26, 2001, the court issued a final judgment that ordered Visa U.S.A. to repeal bylaw 2.10(e) and enjoined Visa U.S.A. and Visa International from
enacting or enforcing any bylaw, rule, policy or practice that prohibits its issuers from issuing general purpose credit or debit cards in the United States on any other general purpose card network. The final judgment also allowed some Visa issuers
to terminate their issuance agreements. The final judgment imposed parallel requirements on MasterCard. After all appeals were exhausted, the final judgment became effective by court order on October&nbsp;15, 2004. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Settlement Service Fee Litigation </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On January&nbsp;10,
2005, MasterCard filed a motion in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York in connection with the DOJ litigation, renewing an earlier challenge to a Visa U.S.A. bylaw that provides for a settlement service fee. To ensure
payment of Visa U.S.A.&#146;s settlement obligation in the<I> In re Visa Check/</I> <I>MasterMoney Antitrust Litigation</I> case, Visa U.S.A. adopted the settlement service fee bylaw in June 2003. The bylaw provided that the settlement service fee
is to be paid by certain Visa U.S.A. members that shift a substantial portion of their offline debit volume to another debit brand unless that shift is to the American Express or Discover brands. MasterCard contended that the settlement service fee
violated the final judgment in the DOJ litigation by effectively prohibiting Visa U.S.A. members from issuing MasterCard debit cards. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On
August&nbsp;18, 2005, the court issued an order appointing a special master to hear evidence regarding MasterCard&#146;s challenge. An evidentiary hearing before the special master occurred in December 2005. In July 2006, the special master
submitted his Findings of Fact and Conclusions of Law to the court, in which he concluded that Visa U.S.A. did not violate the final judgment in the DOJ action before October&nbsp;15, 2004&#151;the effective date of the Final Judgment&#151;but that
Visa U.S.A. did violate the final judgment by continuing to enforce the settlement service fee after October&nbsp;15, 2004. Visa U.S.A. filed objections to the special master&#146;s report and MasterCard asked the court to adopt the special
master&#146;s findings and conclusions. The court heard oral argument with respect to the proper scope of any remedy on April&nbsp;23, 2007. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On
June&nbsp;7, 2007, the court issued an Opinion and Order holding that the settlement service fee violated the final judgment in the DOJ case as of October&nbsp;15, 2004.&nbsp;On June&nbsp;15, 2007, the court issued an Amended Opinion and Order,
clarifying the remedy in the ruling. First, the court ordered Visa U.S.A. to repeal the settlement service fee bylaw.&nbsp;Second, the court gave any Visa U.S.A. debit issuer subject </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">185 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>VISA INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>September 30, 2008 </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(in millions, except as noted) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">to the settlement service fee prior to its repeal that entered into an agreement that includes offline debit issuance with Visa U.S.A. on or after June&nbsp;20, 2003
the right to terminate its agreement, provided that the issuer has entered into an agreement to issue MasterCard branded debit cards and the issuer repays to Visa U.S.A. any unearned benefits or financial incentives under its Visa U.S.A. agreement.
On June&nbsp;13, 2007, the parties entered into an agreement to toll the statute of limitations on certain potential claims MasterCard may have against Visa U.S.A. in connection with the settlement service fee. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Pursuant to the court&#146;s order, the settlement service fee bylaw was rescinded as of the effective date of the order. On June&nbsp;29, 2007, Visa U.S.A. filed
a notice of appeal to the Second Circuit Court of Appeals. Visa U.S.A. also sought a stay pending appeal as to the contract termination portion of the court&#146;s remedy, which the District Court denied. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On August&nbsp;17, 2007, Discover Financial Services and DFS Services LLC (collectively, Discover) moved the District Court to intervene in the settlement service
fee matter. Discover also sought to have the District Court modify its June&nbsp;15, 2007 order to (1)&nbsp;extend the contract termination remedy to issuers entering into agreements with Discover; and (2)&nbsp;void certain provisions of Visa
U.S.A.&#146;s debit agreements. The court denied Discover&#146;s motion on October&nbsp;12, 2007. On September&nbsp;11, 2007, Discover filed a motion to intervene in the settlement service fee case in the Second Circuit and asked the Second Circuit
to remand the case to the District Court. Visa U.S.A. opposed Discover&#146;s motion. Briefing is complete but no decision has been issued by the Second Circuit. The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit proposed that oral argument on
Visa&#146;s appeal take place the week of June&nbsp;23, 2008. At the request of the parties, the Second Circuit adjourned the oral argument scheduled for June. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">In July 2008, Visa received from MasterCard a full release of certain potential claims MasterCard may have against Visa U.S.A. in connection with the settlement service fee and other matters. Visa agreed to withdraw its appeal
of the district court&#146;s order in the settlement service fee litigation. The Second Circuit entered the withdrawal with prejudice on August&nbsp;5, 2008. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2"><B><I>New Zealand Interchange Proceedings </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">The Commerce Commission, New Zealand&#146;s competition regulator, filed a civil Statement
of Claim in the High Court in Wellington on November&nbsp;9, 2006, alleging that, among other things, the fixing of default interchange rates by Cards NZ Limited, Visa International, MasterCard and certain Visa International member financial
institutions contravenes the New Zealand Commerce Act.&nbsp;On November&nbsp;27, 2006, a group of New Zealand retailers filed a nearly identical claim against the same parties before the same tribunal. Both the Commerce Commission and the retailers
seek declaratory, injunctive and monetary relief.&nbsp;On March&nbsp;2, 2007, Visa International filed statements of defense in both cases, denying liability for any cause of action. Both cases were transferred to the commercial list at the High
Court in Auckland in April 2007. The court approved a timetable for initial discovery and other procedural matters in June 2007; such discovery is now proceeding. In March 2008, the court set a trial date in October 2009 for this matter. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B><I>Currency Conversion Litigation </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">In 2000, a
&#147;representative&#148; action was filed in California state court against Visa U.S.A. and Visa International in connection with an asserted 1% currency conversion &#147;fee&#148; assessed on member financial institutions by the payment card
networks on transactions involving the purchase of goods or </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">186 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>VISA INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>September 30, 2008 </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(in millions, except as noted) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">services in a foreign currency and the disclosure of that fee (<I>Schwartz v. Visa International Corp. (sic), et al.</I>). Plaintiffs claimed Visa&#146;s currency
conversion practices violated California Business&nbsp;&amp; Professions Code Section&nbsp;17200, and sought injunctive relief and restitution. Additional California state currency conversion class actions were filed against Visa U.S.A. and Visa
International. <I>Shrieve v. Visa U.S.A. Inc., et al. </I>alleged that Visa had a duty to inform cardholders using debit cards overseas of the existence of the 1% currency conversion fee. <I>Mattingly v. Visa U.S.A. Inc., et al</I>. alleged Visa had
a duty to inform cardholders using credit cards overseas of the existence of the 1% currency conversion fee. <I>Baker v. Visa International Corp</I>. <I>(sic), et al</I>. challenged Visa International&#146;s calculation of currency conversion rates
and the disclosure of those rates. All plaintiffs sought restitution and injunctive relief. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Visa U.S.A., Visa International, MasterCard, Citicorp
Diners Club, Inc. (Diners Club) and several Visa U.S.A. and Visa International member financial institutions, and in some cases their affiliates and parents, are also defendants in a number of federal class actions that allege, among other things,
violations of federal antitrust laws based on the 1% currency conversion fee. Pursuant to orders of the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation, the federal complaints were consolidated or coordinated in MDL 1409 (<I>In re Currency Conversion Fee
Antitrust Litigation</I>) in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On July&nbsp;20, 2006, Visa U.S.A. and Visa
International entered into a settlement agreement in MDL 1409. Under the terms of that settlement, the defendants, which include Visa U.S.A., Visa International, MasterCard, Citicorp Diners Club Inc. and several banks, will pay $336.0 million to
settle monetary claims by eligible cardholders, the costs of administering the settlement and notice to cardholders and any court-approved fees and expenses to attorneys for the class and awards to the class representatives. Visa U.S.A. and Visa
International&#146;s portion of the settlement payment, which has already been paid into a settlement fund, is approximately $100.1 million. In addition, Visa U.S.A. and Visa International agreed that for five years they would separately identify or
itemize any fees added to transactions because they occurred in a foreign country or involved a foreign currency and would require U.S. issuing members to disclose certain changes, if any, to exchange rate practices. As part of this settlement,
plaintiffs in <I>Shrieve</I> and <I>Mattingly</I> agreed that they would ask the court to dismiss their actions with prejudice as to Visa U.S.A. and Visa International once the MDL 1409 settlement receives court approval. Visa U.S.A., Visa
International and MasterCard further agreed to pay $32.0 million in attorneys&#146; fees to resolve <I>Schwartz</I>. Visa U.S.A. and Visa International&#146;s portion of this payment is approximately $18.6 million, which was paid into a settlement
fund in September 2007. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Finally, Visa U.S.A. and Visa International entered into a settlement in <I>Baker</I>. Under the terms of this settlement
agreement, the parties agreed to undertake their best efforts to secure certain changes to the notice of settlement to be provided to class members in MDL 1409, and plaintiffs agreed not to object or otherwise oppose approval of the MDL settlement
agreement. Upon final approval of the MDL settlement agreement, plaintiffs shall seek to dismiss <I>Baker</I>. If <I>Baker</I> is dismissed, Visa U.S.A. and Visa International shall pay $1 million plus interest from September&nbsp;14, 2006 as
attorneys&#146; fees and costs. If, however, within 60 days of final approval of the MDL settlement agreement, <I>Baker</I> has still not been dismissed, Visa U.S.A. and Visa International shall pay $500,000 plus interest from September&nbsp;14,
2006 as attorneys&#146; fees and costs. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On November&nbsp;8, 2006, the court in MDL 1409 issued an order preliminarily approving the MDL settlement
agreement. Among other things, this order created, for settlement purposes only, a Settlement Damages Class consisting of holders of U.S. issued Visa- or MasterCard-branded credit </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">187 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>

<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>VISA INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>September 30, 2008 </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(in millions, except as noted) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">and debit cards or Diners Club-branded credit cards who used their cards to make a foreign payment transaction between February&nbsp;10, 1996 and November&nbsp;8,
2006, the Settlement Damages Class. The court also approved, for settlement purposes only, the &#147;Settlement Injunctive Class,&#148; which contains all persons who held a U.S. issued Visa- or MasterCard-branded credit or debit card or Diners
Club-branded credit card as of November&nbsp;8, 2006. Charge cards are included in the definition of &#147;credit cards.&#148; On November&nbsp;14, 2006, the plaintiff in one case coordinated with MDL 1409 (<I>Bildstein v. MasterCard International
Incorporated)</I> filed a Notice of Appeal from the grant of preliminary approval. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Notice of the settlement began in 2007. In view of concerns
raised by putative class members, the court appointed a special master to work with the parties to review and amend, as appropriate, the plan for class notice and distribution of the settlement fund and to determine whether the proposed settlement
agreement is fair, adequate and reasonable with respect to all class members. The special master submitted his report on or about July&nbsp;10, 2007, and recommended that the plan for notice and distribution of the fund be modified. On
August&nbsp;13, 2007, the court issued an order approving the claims procedure recommended by the special master. On September&nbsp;24, 2007, the court issued an order approving the revised notices, claim forms and settlement schedule submitted by
the parties. Revised notices and claim forms will be mailed to identified class members in late November, and a revised publication notice will run in late November and early December. Class members will have until February&nbsp;14, 2008 to object
to or opt-out of the settlement. The Court moved the hearing on entry of Final Judgment and Order of Dismissal to March&nbsp;31, 2008. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Based upon
the court&#146;s preliminary approval of the MDL 1409 settlement and other developments, approximately $100.1 million and $18.6 million have been paid into a settlement funds to resolve these claims against Visa U.S.A. and Visa International, and a
legal accrual of approximately $1.0 million has been made for the remainder of the settlement in connection with these currency conversion cases. Should the MDL settlement agreement not receive final court approval, or otherwise terminate, we
anticipate that the parties in all of the Currency Conversion Litigation actions would return to the <I>status quo ante</I> in their respective actions. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2">On February&nbsp;14, 2008, the United States Department of Justice filed an objection on behalf of the United States to the settlement. Among other things, the objection states that the United States is not a member of the class covered by
the settlement. Thus, any claims that the United States may have against Visa or its member banks relating to foreign transactions will not be released by the settlement. On May&nbsp;20, 2008 and June&nbsp;4, 2008, the Department of Justice
submitted letters to the court related to its pending objection. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On March&nbsp;31, 2008, the court held a hearing on whether to approve the
settlement and enter the Final Judgment and Order of Dismissal. The matter remains under submission. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B><I>Morgan Stanley Dean Witter/Discover Litigation </I></B>
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">In August 2004, the European Commission in Brussels issued a Statement of Objections against Visa International and Visa Europe alleging a breach of
European competition law. The allegation arises from the Visa International and Visa Europe Rule (bylaw 2.12(b)) that makes certain designated competitors, including Morgan Stanley Dean Witter/Discover, ineligible for membership. On October&nbsp;3,
2007, the European Commission fined Visa International and Visa Europe <FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#128;</FONT><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"></FONT>10.2&nbsp;million ($14.5 million) for infringing European Union rules on restrictive
business practices (Article 81 of the EC Treaty and </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">188 </FONT></P>

<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>VISA INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>September 30, 2008 </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(in millions, except as noted) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Article 53 of the EEA Agreement). Visa International and Visa Europe filed an appeal of the ruling with the Court of First Instance on December&nbsp;19, 2007. The
European Commission filed a defence on June&nbsp;9, 2008 and Visa International and Visa Europe filed their rejoinder on September&nbsp;29, 2008. Pursuant to existing agreements, Visa Europe has acknowledged full responsibility for the defense of
this action, including any fines that may be payable. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B><I>Parke Litigation </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On June&nbsp;27, 2005, a purported consumer and merchant class action was filed in California state court against Visa U.S.A., Visa International, MasterCard, Merrick Bank and CardSystems Solutions, Inc. The complaint stems
from a data-security breach at CardSystems, a payment card processor that handled Visa and other payment brand transactions. The complaint alleges that Visa U.S.A. and Visa International&#146;s failure to inform cardholders of the CardSystems breach
in a timely manner constitutes an unlawful and/or unfair business practice under California&#146;s Unfair Competition Law and violates California&#146;s statutory privacy-notice law. In August 2005, the court denied the plaintiffs&#146; application
for a temporary restraining order, except with respect to the defendants&#146; retention of affected account-identifying information, and in September 2005 denied plaintiffs&#146; motion for a preliminary injunction. Also in September 2005, the
court dismissed the claims brought by the merchant class. On November&nbsp;18, 2005, the defendants answered the remaining claims. Limited discovery occurred. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">CardSystems filed for bankruptcy in U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona in May 2006, staying the litigation as to it. The plaintiffs removed the case to U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California on
August&nbsp;10, 2006, and then sought to transfer the case to federal court in Arizona. Visa U.S.A., Visa International and MasterCard moved for remand to state court. On October&nbsp;11, 2006, the court granted the defendants&#146; motion for
remand and denied the plaintiffs&#146; motion to transfer the case. Proceedings involving CardSystems continue in the bankruptcy court in Arizona, and the California state court plaintiffs appear to be pursuing claims against CardSystems in that
forum. The state court in California has not set discovery deadlines or a trial date. The parties are currently engaged in settlement negotiations. The potential settlement amount is not considered material to the Company&#146;s consolidated
financial statements. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B><I>The ATM Exchange Litigation </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2">On November&nbsp;14, 2005, The ATM Exchange filed a complaint for money damages against Visa U.S.A. and Visa International in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Ohio. The plaintiff asserts claims of promissory estoppel,
negligent misrepresentation and fraudulent misrepresentation, alleging that Visa&#146;s deferment of a July&nbsp;1, 2004 member deadline that required newly deployed ATMs to be certified by a Visa- recognized laboratory as meeting certain PIN-entry
device testing requirements harmed the plaintiff by reducing demand for its ATM upgrade solution. The parties engaged in written discovery, party and third-party depositions and expert discovery. On June&nbsp;29, 2007, Visa U.S.A. and Visa
International filed motions for summary judgment on liability and damages. On July&nbsp;30, 2007, the court vacated the tentative September 2007 trial date. The court indicated that it would set another trial date, if necessary, in its forthcoming
ruling on the motions for summary judgment. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On August&nbsp;14, 2008, the district court entered an order denying Visa&#146;s motion for summary
judgment on liability. On October&nbsp;21, 2008, the court denied Visa&#146;s motion for summary judgment on damages. A new trial date has not been set. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">189 </FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>VISA INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>September 30, 2008 </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(in millions, except as noted) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B><I>District of Columbia Civil Investigative Demand </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On January&nbsp;5,
2007, the Office of the Attorney General for the District of Columbia issued a Civil Investigative Demand, or &#147;CID,&#148; to Visa U.S.A. seeking information regarding a potential violation of Section&nbsp;28-4502 of the District of Columbia
Antitrust Act. The D.C. Attorney General&#146;s office is coordinating parallel investigations by the Attorneys General of New York and Ohio. The CID seeks documents and narrative responses to several interrogatories and document requests, which
focus on PIN debit. Visa U.S.A. continues to cooperate with the Attorneys General in connection with the CID. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On July&nbsp;1, 2008, Visa U.S.A.
amended its rules relating to the routing of so-called &#147;PINless debit&#148; transactions. In conjunction with that change, the office of the Attorney General of the District of Columbia has notified Visa U.S.A. that it considers Visa U.S.A. to
have complied with the CID issued on January&nbsp;5, 2007 and that Visa U.S.A.&#146;s rule change responds to concerns that led to its investigation. The Attorneys General of New York and Ohio, who were conducting parallel investigations, have
similarly notified Visa U.S.A. that the rule change responds to the concerns that led to their investigations. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B><I>U.S. Department of Justice Civil Investigative
Demands </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On September&nbsp;26, 2007, the Antitrust Division of the United States Department of Justice (the &#147;Division&#148;) issued a
Civil Investigative Demand, or &#147;CID,&#148; to Visa U.S.A. seeking information regarding a potential violation of Section&nbsp;1 or 2 of the Sherman Act, 15 U.S.C. &#167;&#167; 1, 2. The CID seeks documents, data and narrative responses to
several interrogatories and document requests, which focus on PIN debit and Visa&#146;s No Signature Required program. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On July&nbsp;1, 2008, the
Division notified Visa U.S.A. that the rule change announced by Visa U.S.A. regarding the routing of PINless debit transactions addressed the concerns that led the Division to issue the CID on September&nbsp;26, 2007. The Division has closed this
investigation. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On September&nbsp;27, 2007, the Division issued a second CID to Visa U.S.A., also seeking information regarding a potential violation
of Section&nbsp;1 or 2 of the Sherman Act, 15 U.S.C. &#167;&#167; 1, 2. The CID seeks documents in response to several requests, which focus on Visa U.S.A.&#146;s agreements with banks that issue Visa debit cards. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On February&nbsp;26, 2008, the Division issued a third CID to Visa U.S.A., seeking information regarding a potential violation of the Final Judgment, dated
November&nbsp;26, 2001, in <I>United States v. Visa U.S.A. Inc. et al</I>., 163 F.Supp.2d 322 (S.D.N.Y. 2001). The CID seeks documents, data and narrative responses to several interrogatories and document requests, which focus on alleged termination
and waiver provisions in certain agreements between Visa U.S.A. and Visa issuers. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On October&nbsp;10, 2008, the Division issued a fourth CID to Visa
U.S.A., seeking information regarding a potential violation of Section&nbsp;1 or 2 of the Sherman Act, 15 U.S.C. &#167;&#167; 1, 2. The CID seeks documents, data and narrative responses to several interrogatories and document requests, which focus
on certain Visa U.S.A. policies relating to merchant acceptance practices, including Visa U.S.A.&#146;s policies regarding merchant surcharging and merchants&#146; ability to steer customers to other forms of payment. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Visa U.S.A. is cooperating with the Division in connection with all CIDs. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">190 </FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>VISA INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"

STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(in millions, except as noted) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B><I>AAA Antiques Mall </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On November&nbsp;13, 2007, a putative class
action lawsuit was filed in Maryland state court against Visa U.S.A., MasterCard Worldwide, and Discover Financial Services.&nbsp;Plaintiff AAA Antiques Mall, Inc. alleges that &#147;credit card fees&#148; assessed by defendants as to the state tax
portion of a sales transaction constitute unjust enrichment and/or intentional misrepresentation.</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On February&nbsp;1, 2008, Visa U.S.A. filed a
motion for summary judgment, or, in the alternative, motion to dismiss all claims brought against it. The court granted Visa U.S.A.&#146;s motion and dismissed the case against all defendants on June&nbsp;12, 2008. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B><I>Hill Country Custom Cycles </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Robert Smith, individually and doing
business as Hill Country Custom Cycles, filed a putative class action lawsuit against Visa Inc., several banks, and a processor in U.S. District Court for the Central District of California on June&nbsp;4, 2008. The plaintiff alleges that, due to
fluctuations in currency conversion rates, a transaction disputed by a cardholder and ultimately charged back to a merchant by its acquiring bank (a &#147;chargeback&#148;) may result in a debit to a merchant&#146;s account in excess of the original
transaction amount. The lawsuit asserts claims under federal and state antitrust law and a variety of common law claims, including fraud and breach of contract. On October&nbsp;14, 2008, Visa Inc. filed a motion to dismiss all claims brought against
it. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B><I>Venezuela Interchange Proceedings </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On
October&nbsp;2, 2008, the Superintendencia para la Promoci&oacute;n y Protecci&oacute;n de la Libre Competencia (Competition Authority) of Venezuela filed an administrative proceeding against &#147;Visa Inc. International&#148; (sic), MasterCard,
American Express, Diners Club, Consorcio Credicard, and more than thirty privately held financial institutions. The Competition Authority alleges that, among other things, the defendants&#146; setting of default interchange rates and merchant
discount rates violates Venezuelan competition law. The Competition Authority seeks monetary and injunctive relief. At this early stage, it is not possible to make any reasonable evaluation of the claims alleged. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B><I>Intellectual Property Litigation </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Cryptography Research </I>
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On September&nbsp;29, 2004, Cryptography Research, Inc. (&#147;CRI&#148;) filed suit against Visa International in U.S. District Court for the North
District of California asserting claims for breach of contract, misrepresentation, and infringement of eight U.S. patents. These causes of action are based upon CRI&#146;s allegations that Visa International has improperly used, or induced others to
use, technology allegedly developed by CRI for securing &#147;Smart Cards&#148; against attacks designed to discover secret information, such as the secret key for performing cryptographic operations. On March&nbsp;7, 2005, CRI filed an amended
complaint identifying claims for breach of contract, misrepresentation, fraud in the inducement and infringement of the eight Patents in Suit. The breach of contract, misrepresentation and fraud in the inducement claims stem from a September&nbsp;2,
1998 Intellectual Property License Agreement between CRI and Visa International. The license agreement granted Visa International worldwide rights to CRI&#146;s patent applications that ultimately matured into the Patents in Suit. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">191 </FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>VISA INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>September 30, 2008 </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(in millions, except as noted) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On March&nbsp;22, 2007, CRI filed its Second Amended Complaint, adding claims for breach of fiduciary duty and violation of Section&nbsp;1 of the Sherman Act and
California&#146;s Unfair Competition Law. CRI further alleges that Visa International is liable under California&#146;s Cartwright Act, Bus.&nbsp;&amp; Prof. Code Sections 16720-70 and the California Business&nbsp;&amp; Professions Code &#167;&#167;
17200 et seq. Visa International filed its answer to the Second Amended Complaint and related counterclaims on April&nbsp;23, 2007. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Discovery in
this matter is currently ongoing and is scheduled to be completed on May&nbsp;12, 2008. A patent claims construction hearing was held on November&nbsp;8 and 9, 2005. Four claims construction orders have been issued. CRI filed a motion for
reconsideration of the second order, and a hearing on that motion was held September&nbsp;10, 2007. No ruling on CRI&#146;s motion has been issued. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2">CRI filed its Third Amended Complaint on March&nbsp;14, 2008. Visa International moved to dismiss the antitrust claims in the Third Amended Complaint, and the Court has taken the motion under submission without oral argument.&nbsp;On
March&nbsp;27, 2008, CRI sought leave to file a supplemental complaint, in which it would add Visa Inc. as an additional defendant to the claims of patent infringement, unfair competition, and antitrust violations that were alleged against Visa
International in the Third Amended Complaint. On May&nbsp;8, 2008, the court granted CRI leave to file the supplemental complaint, which was served on Visa Inc. on May&nbsp;9, 2008. Visa Inc. filed a motion to dismiss the supplemental complaint on
June&nbsp;30, 2008. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On September&nbsp;11, 2008, the parties executed a global settlement agreement resolving the claims in this case. The amount of
the settlement is not material to the Company&#146;s financial statements taken as a whole. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Vale Canjeable </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On November&nbsp;21, 2006, Vale Canjeable Ticketven, C.A., filed an action in the Fifth Municipal Court of Caracas, Venezuela against Todoticket 2004, C.A., and
Visa International seeking a preliminary injunction preventing use of the Visa Vale mark in Venezuela. In December 2006, Vale Canjeable Ticketven, C.A. also filed a claim with the Fourth Commercial Court of First Instance of Caracas, alleging that
the defendants infringed the plaintiff&#146;s rights as the holder of the trademark registries and requesting declarative, injunctive and monetary relief. The plaintiff also requested that the court order the defendants to pay the legal costs and
expenses related to the judicial process. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On November&nbsp;29, 2006, the Fifth Municipal Court of Caracas granted a preliminary injunction
prohibiting use of the &#147;Vale&#148; in the Venezuelan market of food vouchers. On December&nbsp;6, 2006, Visa International filed a constitutional objection to the court&#146;s ruling. The objection was dismissed on December&nbsp;19, 2006 by the
Fourth Commercial Court of First Instance of Caracas. Visa International appealed this decision, which was denied in March 2007. On March&nbsp;21, 2007, defendants filed a motion with the Fourth Commercial Court of First Instance of Caracas, seeking
revocation of the preliminary injunction granted by the Fifth Municipal Court of Caracas. This motion was denied on July&nbsp;11, 2007. Visa International immediately filed an appeal of this decision with the Superior Court. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On July&nbsp;26, 2007, Visa International made a request for the removal of the First Instance Judge from the case and such request was granted on
September&nbsp;25, 2007. A new judge was assigned to finalize the discovery phase of the case. On November&nbsp;1, 2007, Visa International filed its written conclusions explaining how the evidence collected during discovery supports its arguments.
On November&nbsp;21, 2007, Visa International filed an appeal of the decision denying suspension of the </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>VISA INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>September 30, 2008 </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(in millions, except as noted) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">preliminary injunction with the newly assigned judge. The plaintiff filed a response to this appeal on November&nbsp;26, 2007, and Visa replied to that response on
December&nbsp;3, 2007. The appeal was denied on December&nbsp;18, 2007. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On March&nbsp;14, 2008, Visa International filed an extraordinary
appeal&nbsp;of the preliminary injunction ruling with the Commercial Chamber of the Supreme Court. On August&nbsp;6, 2008, the Commercial Chamber of the Supreme Court accepted Visa International&#146;s appeal and declared null and void the decision
from the Superior Tribunal that dismissed Visa International&#146;s earlier appeal against the preliminary measures granted by the First Instance Tribunal. Pursuant to the Supreme Court&#146;s order, a new Superior Tribunal will issue a new decision
on the appeal against the preliminary measures. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Starpay and VIMachine </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On May&nbsp;8, 2003, Starpay and VIMachine sued Visa U.S.A. and Visa International in U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas, claiming that Visa
used information provided by Starpay in 2000 to create VbV and to file a Visa patent application on the technology underlying VbV. Two claims are asserted: infringement of VIMachine&#146;s patent and misappropriation of Starpay&#146;s trade secrets.
On February&nbsp;23, 2004, Visa U.S.A. and Visa International answered the complaint and filed a counterclaim for a declaratory judgment that Visa U.S.A. and Visa International are not infringing the asserted patent and/or that the patent is
invalid. On March&nbsp;16, 2004, Starpay filed its answer to Visa U.S.A. and Visa International&#146;s counterclaim. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">The Magistrate Judge held
hearings on the issue of the construction of various claims of the patent and on January&nbsp;19, 2006 issued a Report and Recommendation making findings and recommendations. In February 2006, the parties filed their respective objections to the
Report with the District Court Judge. On September&nbsp;10, 2007, the District Court issued an order resolving the parties&#146; various objections and finalized the claim construction.&nbsp;The court has set a schedule that calls for the completion
of discovery&nbsp;by April&nbsp;18, 2008 and the&nbsp;filing of any&nbsp;dispositive motions by&nbsp;May 16, 2008.&nbsp;No trial date has been set. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2">On January&nbsp;7, 2008, Visa U.S.A. and Visa International filed a Motion for Partial Summary Judgment of Non-Infringement and/or Invalidity of U.S. Patent No.&nbsp;5,903,878 (&#147;the &#145;878 patent&#148;). The motion was made on the
grounds that (1)&nbsp;the accused VbV system lacks the &#147;unique transaction identifier&#148; element of the claims of the &#145;878 patent; and (2)&nbsp;the &#145;878 patent is invalid in light of at least three prior art patents. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">The parties reached an agreement in principle to settle the dispute in January 2008. On May&nbsp;16, 2008, Visa U.S.A. and Visa International filed a Motion to
Enforce the Settlement Agreement against all parties to the agreement, including the inventor. Briefing is now complete. If the settlement agreement is enforced, the amount of the settlement is not material to the Company&#146;s financial statements
taken as a whole. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>PrivaSys </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On
June&nbsp;20, 2007, PrivaSys, Inc. filed a complaint in U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against Visa International and Visa U.S.A for patent infringement. <I>PrivaSys</I> alleges that Visa&#146;s contactless payment
technology infringes U.S. Patent No.&nbsp;7,195,154, which we refer to as the &#145;154 patent&#146;), entitled &#147;Method for Generating Customer Secure Card Numbers.&#148; Visa U.S.A. and Visa </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">193 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>VISA INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>September 30, 2008 </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(in millions, except as noted) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">International filed their respective answers and counterclaims on August&nbsp;21, 2007 alleging that Visa did not infringe the &#145;154 patent, that the &#145;154
patent is invalid and that the patent is unenforceable due to inequitable conduct and prosecution laches. On September&nbsp;28, 2007, PrivaSys filed a motion requesting leave to file an amended complaint adding J.P. Morgan Chase&nbsp;&amp; Co. and
Wells Fargo&nbsp;&amp; Co. as defendants. Visa U.S.A. and Visa International opposed this motion on October&nbsp;26, 2007 and asked the court, in the alternative, to stay all proceedings against Visa issuing financial institutions pending resolution
of the issue of whether the Visa technology infringes the PrivaSys patent. On November&nbsp;14, 2007, the court granted PrivaSys&#146;s motion for leave to file the amended complaint. On December&nbsp;5, 2007, Visa U.S.A. filed an answer to the
amended complaint. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">The parties reached an agreement in principle to settle the dispute in December 2007. In light of this agreement, on
January&nbsp;9, 2008 the court dismissed the case with prejudice, provided that the settlement is finalized within 90 days of the dismissal. The parties executed the final settlement agreement in February 2008. The amount of the settlement is not
material to the Company&#146;s financial statements taken as a whole. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><I>Every Penny Counts, Inc.&#151;Prepaid Cards </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On July&nbsp;17, 2007, Every Penny Counts, Inc. filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Florida against Visa U.S.A., MasterCard and
American Express for infringement of four of its patents. Plaintiff amended its complaint on September&nbsp;27, 2007 to add Green Dot Corp. as a party and&nbsp;to add a fifth patent to&nbsp;its suit. The Complaint now alleges that the
defendants&#146; &#147;open&#148; prepaid card products infringe U.S. Patent No.&nbsp;5,621,640 (&#147;Automatic Philanthropic Contribution System&#148;). U.S. Patent No.&nbsp;6,112,191 (&#147;Method and System to Create and Distribute Excess Funds
from Consumer Spending Transactions&#148;). U.S. Patent No.&nbsp;6,088,682 (&#147;Funds Distribution System Connected with Point of Sale Transactions&#148;), U.S. Patent No.&nbsp;6,876,971 (&#147;Funds Distribution System Connected with Point of
Sale Transaction&#148;) and U.S. Patent No.&nbsp;7,171,370 (&#147;Funds Distribution System Connected with Point of Sale Transactions&#148;). Visa U.S.A. filed a Motion to Dismiss, or in the Alternative for a More Definite Statement, based
on&nbsp;the plaintiff&#146;s failure to identify which products or services offered by Visa U.S.A. purportedly infringe&nbsp;which of the plaintiff&#146;s patents on October&nbsp;12, 2007. The court denied the motion on October&nbsp;29, 2007. On
November&nbsp;13, 2007, Visa U.S.A. filed its answer and counterclaims alleging that Visa does not infringe the plaintiff&#146;s patents, that the plaintiff&#146;s patents are invalid, and that the plaintiff&#146;s patents are unenforceable to
prosecution laches and inequitable conduct. The court issued an order on December&nbsp;13, 2007 setting procedural deadlines for the claim construction and scheduling a Markman hearing in May 2008. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">At a claims construction hearing on May&nbsp;22, 2008, the court ruled in favor of defendants on all five of plaintiff&#146;s patents. In light of this ruling,
plaintiff orally agreed to a stipulated judgment in favor of all defendants on all claims. The court entered&nbsp;judgment for all defendants on May&nbsp;23, 2008.&nbsp;On June&nbsp;18, 2008, plaintiff filed a notice of appeal to the U.S. Court of
Appeals for the Federal Circuit. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>Note 24&#151;Subsequent Events </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2">In October of 2008, the Company redeemed of 79,748,857 shares of class C (series II) common stock and 35,263,585 shares of class C (series III) common stock held by Visa Europe for a combined total $2.7 billion, less dividends and certain
other adjustments. See <I>Note 4&#151;Visa Europe </I>and<I> Note 16&#151;Stockholders&#146; Equity and Redeemable Shares</I>. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">194 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>

<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>VISA INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>September 30, 2008 </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(in millions, except as noted) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">On October&nbsp;27, 2008, Visa, MasterCard and Discover resolved pending litigation by executing a final settlement agreement that became effective upon approval by
Visa&#146;s Class B shareholders. Visa&#146;s net share of the settlement totals $1.8 billion. See<I> Note 23&#151;Legal Matters.</I> </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Under the
Company&#146;s Retrospective Responsibility Plan, its class B shareholders will bear the cost of funding the escrow account via a further dilutive adjustment in the conversion ratio of their class B shares to shares of class A common stock, reducing
the total number of diluted class A shares outstanding for purposes of calculating EPS. See <I>Note 5&#151;Retrospective Responsibility Plan</I>.<I> </I>On November&nbsp;14, 2008&nbsp;the Company&nbsp;filed a definitive proxy with the Securities and
Exchange Commission seeking to amend&nbsp;its charter to permit&nbsp;the deposit of operating cash directly into the escrow account with a corresponding reduction in the conversion ratio applicable to class B common shares. Funding the escrow
account in this manner would also effectively act as a share repurchase program. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:24px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>Selected Quarterly Financial Data (Unaudited) </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(in millions, except per share data) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">The following tables
show selected quarterly operating results for each quarter and full year of fiscal 2008 for Visa Inc. and of fiscal 2007 for Visa U.S.A. Inc.: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>VISA INC. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="2"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&#151;(Continued) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>September 30, 2008 </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(in millions, except as noted) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px; margin-left:0%">
<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">entitled to equal per share distributions whether through dividends or upon liquidation. The Company therefore presented a single earnings per share amount applicable
to all outstanding classes of common stock for period presented ending prior to the IPO. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; padding-bottom:3px; margin-top:-2px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="line-height:95%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"></FONT><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>ii</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"></FONT></P></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:95%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Following the IPO, the Company calculated net income per share using the two-class method under the guideline of SFAS No.&nbsp;128
to reflect the different rights of each class and series of outstanding common stock. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; padding-bottom:3px; margin-top:-2px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="line-height:95%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"></FONT><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>iii</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"></FONT></P></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:95%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">Historical balances for periods prior to October&nbsp;1, 2007 represent balances for Visa U.S.A. Inc., deemed the accounting
acquirer in the business combination. Visa U.S.A. Inc. was a non-stock corporation and therefore there was no comparable metric for net income per share. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;
</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2">196 </FONT></P>
